title: Former Tory leader William Hague slams expulsion of rebel MPs as ‘disgusting act of hypocrisy’
text:
Former U.K. Conservative Party leader William Hague | Jack Taylor/Getty Images Former Tory leader William Hague slams expulsion of rebel MPs as ‘disgusting act of hypocrisy’ Boris Johnson’s decision to expel 21 Conservative MPs from party was ‘the most egregious and counter-productive act of self-harm.’

Former U.K. Conservative Party leader William Hague slammed Prime Minister Boris Johnson's decision to expel 21 Tory rebels as "the most egregious and counter-productive act of self-harm committed by the party leadership" in his lifetime.

Johnson expelled the MPs from the Tory party after they voted against the government and in favor of legislation to block a no-deal Brexit on October 31.

"It is not possible to be aware of their record and characters without thinking that their expulsion from the parliamentary ranks of the Conservative Party, partly at the behest of people who have spent years rebelling, is a disgusting act of hypocrisy," Hague wrote in a column in the Telegraph on Monday.

The former Conservative leader called the move a "serious miscalculation" rather than a "show of strength and discipline." The loss of the government's majority will make securing a general election harder, leaving the Tories "more exposed to further defeats and humiliation" in the intervening period, Hague argued.

"Worse still, when the election finally comes, some of those seats might now be denied to the Conservatives," he added.

But he warned disgruntled MPs to avoid wreaking further destruction, writing: "Britain needs a strong and united party of the center right if it is not to become the battleground of extremism."

Hague urged Johnson to use the Conservative conference at the end of the month to steer the party back on track, setting "the tone from the outset of an inclusive and welcoming party."
description: Boris Johnson’s decision to expel 21 Conservative MPs from party was ‘the most egregious and counter-productive act of self-harm.’
